Sentences about perception, animals, verb tenses Sonny Davis and Vina Smith 2010 Unpublished (recorded by Andrew Garrett and Line Mikkelsen on October 25, 2010)
tá
ni thítiv .
ta nithitiv.
I heard it.
tá
ni thítiv .
ta nithitiv.
I heard it.
tá
nu thítiv .
ta nuthitiv.
We all heard it.
tá
ni thítiv
pa púsihich .
ta nithitiv papusihich.
I heard the cat.
tá
ni máh
pa púsihich .
ta nimah papusihich.

pa púsihich .
ta nimah papusihich.

nu mah .
iim ta numah.
I see you (sg).
iim
tá
nu mah .
iim ta numah.
I see you (sg).
tá
ni mah .
ta nimah.
I see it.
tá
nu mah .
ta numah.
We all see it.
ni máh eesh .
nimaheesh.
I will see it.
pa púsihich
îin
tá
ná mah .
papusihich iin ta namah.
The cat sees me. This use of îin doesn't fit dictionary description regarding personal inflection on following verb.
pa púsihich
u máh tih
iim .
papusihich umahtih iim.
The cat sees you. Glottalization in the personal inflection - hesitation? 3sg/2sg is supposed to trigger 'i-...-ap
pa púsihich
iim
t u mah .
papusihich iim tumah.
The cat sees you.

um .

Do you have lots of cats? um after each word; unexpected use of this verb with plural object - WB has tâaraha for have with plural objects

pa nini púsihich .
taay paninipusihich.
I have lots of cats.

uum
taay
pa púsihich
u thiiná tih .

ni thítiim tih
pa púsihich
uum .

I hear the cat No translation offered; v~m in verb root following WB:G342
pa púsihich
ni thítiim ti
u pakurîihvu tih .
papusihich nithitiimti upakuriihvutih.
I hear the cat purring. v~m in verb root following WB:G342; tih does not condition lengthening of final syllable of stem because stem is vowel final
pa púsihich
u pakurîihvu tih .
papusihich upakuriihvutih.
The cat is purring.
tá

pa púsihich

ní muus tih
uum
pa púsihich
u 'áam tih .
nimuustih uum papusihich u'aamtih.
I am looking at the cat eating.
pa púsihich
u 'áam tih .
papusihich u'aamtih.
The cat is eating.
pa púsihich
u 'áam tih .
papusihich u'aamtih.

pa púsihich
íp
t u 'áv at .
papusihich ip tu'avat.

púsihich
ipít

pusihich ipit tu'avat.

pa púsihich
tá
ni 'áfish .
papusihich ta ni'afish.
I'm touching the cat.
pa púsihich
tá
na 'áfish .
papusihich ta na'afish.
The cat is touching me. na- fails to attract acute accent because stem has acute accent of the fixed type (due to VcV shape)
pa púsihich
tá
kun váthiv .
papusihich ta kunvathiv.
The cats are fighting. tá sounds more like tu here, but another repetition clearly has tá.
tá
ni thítiv
pa yupsítanach
u xrára tih .
ta nithitiv payupsitanach uxraratih.
I hear the baby crying.
yáxa
pa púsihich .
yaxa papusihich.
Look at the cat!
fâat
u kupavêenahi .
faat ukupaveenahi.
What is it doing? verb can be broken down into: kupa-...-aha 'modal' (G732), vêen 'to pray' (perh. orig. 'to do')
tá
ni thítiv
pa púsihich
îikam .
ta nithitiv papusihich iikam.
I hear the cat outside.

pa púsihich
îikam
u vathíiv tih .
ta nithitiv papusihich iikam uvathiivtih.
I hear the cats fighting outside.
taay
púsihich
tá
ni mah .
taay pusihich ta nimah.
I see lots of cats.
púfaat
pa púsihich .
pufaat papusihich.
There are no cats.
púfaat
pa púsihich .
pufaat papusihich.
There are no cats.
arara chúupha
nuu
payêem
nu chúupi tih .
ararachuupha nuu payeem nuchuupitih.
We are talking our Indian language now. The vowel in nuu doesn't sound long, but nuu seems the best parse
yánava
koovúra
kun ivyíhuk .
yanava koovura kunivyihuk.
Look they all came!
yánava
pa kúusrah
t óo kfuk
súpaah .
yanava pakuusrah tookfuk supaah.
Look the sun is getting up. Is "tóo kfuk súpaah" the right parse?
ta ni
kúnish
ni thítiv
pa chishíih
p oo hyíiv tih .
tani kunish nithitiv pachishiih poohyiivtih.
I heard the dog barking. What is tani? What is kunish doing here?
yánava
pa chishíih
p oo hyíiv tih .
yanava pachishiih poohyiivtih.
The dogs are barking. -tih conditions vowel lengthening in the final syllable of verb root and accute accent on that vowel by special progressive accentuation.
u hyíiv tih .
uhyiivtih.
It is barking.
yupthúkirar
u xrára tih .
yupthukirar uxraratih.
A mountain lion is crying.
vírusur
uum
taay
p oo xrúunha tih .
virusur uum taay pooxruunhatih.
The bear is growling a lot.
súva nik
tá
ni mah .
suvanik ta nimah.
I see it later on (?)
súva nik
nu máh eesh .
suvanik numaheesh.
I will see you later.
nu
ni 'áasish
ni kyív it
xás
vúra
fâatva
ni thítiv .
nu ni'aasish nikyivit xas vura faatva nithitiv.
When I was sleeping I heard something. What is nu? Why two inflected verbs in a row? Is it some kind of complex predicate? "I fall down" doesn't really make sense semantically. Could it be "nikik" (a little bit) + something?
taahkúnish
pa mu 'ífunih .
taahkunish pamu'ifunih.
Her hair is white.
Vina
mu 'ífuni
uum
taahkúnish .
Vina mu'ifuni uum taahkunish.
Vina has white hair.
hôoy
uum
pa 'ikxáramkunish
púsihich .
hooy uum pa'ikxaramkunish pusihich.
Where is the black cat? initial ik- of 2240 is somewhat reduced
Sentences about driving and directions Sonny Davis and Vina Smith 2010 Unpublished (recorded by Andrew Garrett and Line Mikkelsen on October 25, 2010)

I ate acorn soup. This example does not use the final -at past suffix, at least, it is completely inaudible
xuun
ip

xuun ip ni'avat.
I ate acorn soup. Is xuun accented? If so, why? (It shouldn't -- may just be prosodic?) This example uses the final -at past marker

kupánakanakana. Young brodiaea plant, you must come up quickly. Bright: "This word is used only to end the telling of a myth. It is sometimes followed, as in this case, by a short prayer for food, reflecting the fact that myths were originally told only in the winter, when food was scarce."

"ayiyihanijanee hanijaaneeya." "ayiyihanijanee hanijaaneeya." "ayiyihanijanee hanijaaneeya." Bright: "Coyote's song consists of these meaningless syllables, repeated over and over. No significant pitch or stress can be determined for this sequence; the word-division which is written indicates the phrasing of the melody, rather than a juncture phoneme. The phone 'j,' which has not been found in any other Karuk material, is like that in English 'judge.'"

However, the reasons for Coyote's actions throughout the story (including the cause of his slipping) are obscure; the informant's only explanation was kóova uyúnyuunhitih "he is so crazy." The same story is told of apsunmúnukich, the Western yellow-bellied racer (a snake), in Harrington, 1932b, pp. 27-28."

viriva kuma'ii kunipeenti "xuux mukrivruhvanamich." For that reason they call it "xuux's little rolling-place." Bright: "Duck Hawk's wife is here called xuux; this name designates an extinct and possibly only legendary animal, identified by some informants with the grizzly bear and by others with the African lion."

Bright: "The verb tákuk, translated 'to clean out' in sentence 3, refers to the process of cutting off the projecting sticks on the inside of a basket, after the actual weaving is finished. The heroine, not having time to do this, put her cap on inside out; as a result, the cups of tan oak acorns are prickly, rather than smooth."

1957 William Bright, The Karok Language (1957), pp. 242-243, Text 41 Bright: "This is the only story about Across-the-Water-Widower which I was able to record; one other Karuk story about him appears in Harrington, 1032a, pp.67-72. A character with a similar name is much more prominent in the mythology of the Yurok and the Hupa; cf. Kroeber, 1925, pp.73 and 134."

Bright: "Another informant offered additional information: Before Across-the-Water-Widower's meeting with Tick, men (or rather, male ikxaréeyavs) had penises long enough to wrap several times around their necks, and could copulate with a woman on the other side of the river."

Bright: "This story, if it can actually be called that, is based on the observation that the mockingbird arrives on the Klamath in the summer, at the beginning of salmon season, and leaves in the fall. The swamp robin arrives in the fall, at the beginning of acorn season, and leaves again in the spring."

However, he became tired and lay down to sleep at his first fire, only a short distance from Katimin; cf. Kroeber and Gifford, pp. 116 and 123. The present text was recorded under adverse conditions and is hardly more than a fragment of the complete story."

I climb up there on the Ridge of Long Acorn-Meats Young-Woman. Bright: "According to Kroeber and Gifford, p. 27, xurishaxara'ifápiit, literally 'young woman of long acorn meats,' is 'a word of respect for panther... The regular word is Pirishkarim, but no one uses it lest Panther be angered.' There is evidently some confusion here; the 'regular word' for the panther, i.e., the mountain lion, is yupthúkirar, and this animal is personified as masculine. pirishkâarim, on the other hand, is the 'regular word' for the grizzly bear, which is sometimes identified by the Indians with the African lion, and which is personified as feminine."

A more normal mode of expression would be with... nanitúnviiv 'he thought, 'let my children...'' The unexpected person of the possessive perhaps reflects the structure of English indirect discourse."

Bright: "'Tossel' is what English-speaking Karok call the tákasar or double-ball used in their shinny game; it consists of two short sticks connected by a thong. puyava payu'kukam ta kuntaativrukahaak puyava kari ta kunkookha payuruk va'aras.
If the ones on the downriver end toss it over (the goal line), then the downriver people won.
káru
uumkun
pa ka'kúkam
vúra
kun kuph eesh .
karu uumkun paka'kukam vura kunkupheesh.
Those on the upriver side would do it also.
vaa
uum
pa paaxkív tih an
uum
p eekpihan 'íshiip
káru
p eeshnanich 'íshiip .
vaa uum papaaxkivtihan uum peekpihan'ishiip karu peeshnanich'ishiip.
The winners were the strongest and the swiftest. Bright: "Regarding this game, see Goddard, pp.60-61, and plate 19, figures 3 and 4. Evidently each of the three pairs of players described in the present text consisted of one man from each team. After the middle pair had put the tossel in play, the other pairs would also wrestle, each man trying to keep his opponent from reaching the tossel. In sentences 27 and 28, the terms payu'kúkam 'the downriver side' and paka'kúkam 'the upriver side' evidently do not refer to the pairs of opponents at downriver and upriver ends of the field, but to the downriver and upriver teams, respectively. The course of play is not necessarily, of course, the exact one described in the present text."
"Work Contests" Nettie Reuben
1957 William Bright, The Karok Language (1957), pp. 292-293, Text 79

Bright: "Literally, 'so they don't think, 'Let's tell the children, 'Let's eat here together!'''."

The subtitle is the one associated with the recording in the Berkeley Language Center catalog, but is not in the recording or the Bright transcription; it is unclear if it is correct. *For now*, paragraphs = pages in the original notebook to make things easier to find. **make pdf of just this chunk of manuscript, ask nico to see paper where the title came from, check files/pubs for placenames.
